Hollow NiMo-based nitride heterojunction with super-hydrophilic/aerophobic surface for efficient urea-assisted hydrogen production Yuying Fan Data curation Investigation Writing – original draft a Ying Gu Formal analysis Investigation Methodology b ⁎ Dongxu Wang Formal analysis Investigation a Yanqing Jiao Formal analysis Investigation a Aiping Wu Conceptualization Investigation Methodology Writing – review & editing a ⁎ Chungui Tian Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China, Heilongjiang University, Harbin 150080, Heilongjiang, China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China Heilongjiang University Harbin Heilongjiang 150080 China Key Laboratory of Functional Inorganic Material Chemistry, Ministry of Education of the People’s Republic of China, Heilongjiang University, Harbin 150080, Heilongjiang, China b College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Resource Utilization, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, Heilongjiang, China College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Resource Utilization Northeast Forestry University Harbin Heilongjiang 150040 China College of Chemistry, Chemical Engineering and Resource Utilization, Northeast Forestry University, Harbin 150040, Heilongjiang, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Hollow Ni/NiMoN spheres composed of nano-sheet arrays with optimized interfacial electron structure and superhydrophilic/aerophobic surface are constructed as bifunctional electrocatalysts for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR), which shows a low cell voltage of 1.42 V at 10 mA cm−2 for HER&UOR system. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR) are key reactions of the water-cycling associated catalytic process/device. The design of catalysts with a super-hydrophilic/aerophobic structure and optimized electron distribution holds great promise. Here, we have designed a three-dimensional (3D) hollow Ni/NiMoN hierarchical structure with arrayed-sheet surface based on a one-pot hydrothermal route for efficient urea-assisted HER based on a simple hydrothermal process. The Ni/NiMoN catalyst exhibits super-hydrophilic/aerophobic properties with a small droplet contact angle of 6.07° and an underwater bubble contact angle of 155.7°, thus facilitating an escape of bubbles from the electrodes. Density functional theory calculations and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results indicate the optimized electronic structure at the interface of Ni and NiMoN, which can promote the adsorption/desorption of reactants and intermediates. The virtues combining with a large specific surface area endow Ni/NiMoN with efficient catalytic activity of low potentials of 25 mV for HER and 1.33 V for UOR at 10 mA cm−2. The coupled HER and UOR system demonstrates a low cell voltage of 1.42 V at 10 mA cm−2, which is approximately 209 mV lower than water electrolysis. Keywords Hydrogen evolution Transition metal nitrides Hollow heterojunctions Urea electrooxidation Super hydrophilic/aerophobic 1 Introduction Hydrogen with high energy density and zero carbon emission is an ideal replacement for traditional fuels [1–3]. Hydrogen evolution via electrocatalytic water splitting powered by solar- or wind-derived electricity is a promising route to address the issues [4–6]. It is reasonable to substitute the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) by the more save-energy anode reaction [7–9]. Urea oxidation reaction (UOR) is an alternative to OER due to its lower thermodynamic equilibrium potential (0.37 V vs. 1.23 V) [10–12]. Additionally, it also offers a hopeful approach for the purification of urea wastewater [13,14]. Nowadays, noble metal catalysts are considered as ideal electrocatalysts, but their uses are limited by the high cost and low reserves. The design of the effective non-noble metal-based catalysts by tailoring size, morphology and constructing the heterostructures is promising for the practical development of the field [15]. The bimetallic catalysts with abundant heterogeneous interfaces generally exhibit better performance than the corresponding single compounds [16,17]. Notably, the construction of the super-hydrophilic/aerophobic surface has also received much attention in recent years [18,19]. The manipulation facilitates the contact of catalysts with the water and the escape of bubbles from the electrodes, which is one of the keys to promote the reaction rates involving gases in aqueous phase [20]. The surface properties of electrode materials could be increased by enhancing amorphous region, constructing more defect sites, and introducing hierarchical nanostructure in the electrode material surface [21]. For example, Wang et al. reported that RuO2-modified FeOOH nanosheets with hierarchical structure have super-hydrophilic/aerophobic surface, which guarantees intimate contact with the electrolyte and accelerates the instantaneous escape of produced gas bubbles during the electrocatalytic process [22]. The development of non-noble-metal-based catalysts by the combination of the manipulation of surface properties and structure with electron-regulation engineering is promising for UOR assisted energy-efficient H2 production. The Ni-based materials have been promised in UOR by the formation of Ni3+ active phase (NiOOH) during the anodization process [23–25]. The studies have focused on manipulating the surface property and electronic structure for enhancing the performance [26,27]. The combination of Ni and Mo species with empty d orbitals can accelerate the reaction process based on the “d-electron complementation” effect [28–30]. Typically, the NiSe2/MoSe2 [31] and Mo-doped Ni/NiO [32] have been developed for UOR and HER. Also, a combination of metals (Mo and Ni) with N can give the electronic structure similar to Pt, thus enhancing the catalytic ability for HER/UOR [33]. The Ni x N, Mo x N, and especially the NiMoN have shown large potential as the effective electrocatalysts. A synchronous manipulation of the electronic structure and surface property is useful to give the Ni-Mo based catalysts with improved performance [34,35]. A Ni/NiMoN nanowire array has shown enhanced HER performance benefiting from super-hydrophilic/aerophobic properties (the bubble contact angle is 152°) by promoting the evolution/detachment of gas bubbles [18]. The microstructure and morphology of the catalysts have an important influence on the application performance. The hollow structure provides an microreactor environment with numerous active sites, making it promising for catalytic reaction [36]. There are many reports about the hollow structure composed of small particles from the hard-template route for energy and catalytic application [37]. An array structure is favorable to giving a super-hydrophilic/aerophobic surface [38]. Thus, the design of hollow Ni-Mo based heterojunctions with array structured surface holds promises for effective urea-assisted hydrogen production. Herein, a three-dimensional (3D) hollow Ni/NiMoN heterojunction catalyst with a surface composed of nano-sheet arrays was fabricated for effective urea-assisted hydrogen production. Benefiting from an interconnected nano-sheet arrayed surface, the Ni/NiMoN catalyst exhibits super-hydrophilic/aerophobic properties with a small droplet contact angle of 6.07° and an underwater bubble contact angle of 155.7°, thus facilitating an escape of bubbles from the electrodes. Besides, the interface with an optimized electronic structure can be formed based on electronic interaction of Ni and NiMoN. The Ni/NiMoN catalyst demonstrates excellent HER activity, achieving low overpotentials of 25 and 68 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH. Simultaneously, the Ni/NiMoN catalyst demonstrates a satisfactory UOR activity with the cell voltages of 1.33 and 1.39 V at 10 and 100 mA cm−2. Furthermore, the coupled HER/UOR system based on the catalyst needs a low cell voltage of 1.42 V to achieve the current density of 10 mA cm−2 with good stability, which is 209 mV lower than that of the traditional HER/OER system. The work highlights the significance of combining super-hydrophilic and electron-regulation engineering for energy-efficient hydrogen production. 2 Experimental 2.1 Preparation of 3D hollow nano-sheet arrays Ni/NiMoN catalyst The hollow nano-sheet arrays Ni/NiMoN catalyst was obtained by controllable nitridation of the flower-like NiMoO4 precursor prepared by hydrothermal process. In a simple synthesis, Ni(NO3)3·6H2O (3 mmol), Na2MoO4·2H2O (3 mmol), and 0.12 g urea were added to 80 mL water to obtain green solution under the magnetic stirring. Then, the solution was moved to stainless steel autoclave with a Teflon liner and maintained at 180 °C for 12 h. After natural cooling to room temperature, the light green samples (NiMoO4 precursor) were gathered and cleansed several times with deionized water and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Finally, the precursor was heated at 600 °C for 2 h with a ramp rate of 3 °C min−1 under the NH3 atmosphere to obtain Ni/Ni0.2Mo0.8N catalyst (abbreviated as Ni/NiMoN in the text). To regulate the micro-structures and composition, the nitriding treatment was also performed at 500 °C (Ni/NiMoN-5) and 700 °C (Ni/NiMoN-7) with the other conditions unchanged. 2.2 Preparation of NiMoN catalyst The NiMoN-6E catalyst was acquired by soaking the as-prepared Ni/NiMoN catalyst in 2.0 M HCl solution for 6 h. To better explain the influence of the interaction between Ni and NiMoN on the properties, the experiments with different immersion times were also carried out (marked as NiMoN-6E, NiMoN-12E, and NiMoN-24E respectively). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) results indicate that the metal nickel was almost completely etched after 24 h of etching. Table S1 presents the parameters of the different catalysts in the text. 2.3 Preparation of Ni catalyst The synthesis process of Ni catalyst was same as that of Ni/NiMoN sample except that only 6 mmol Ni(NO3)3·6H2O was added in the hydrothermal process. 2.4 Preparation of Ni/NiN catalyst The synthesis and method for the Ni/NiN catalyst are similar to Ni/NiMoN. Initially, only Ni source (6 mmol) was added during the hydrothermal process, without the addition of the Mo source. Subsequently, the Ni(OH)2 precursor was obtained and heated at 380 °C under NH3 atmosphere for 2 h, resulting in the formation of the Ni/Ni3N catalyst (referred to Ni/NiN in the paper). 2.5 Preparation of Mo3N2 catalyst The synthesis process of Mo3N2 catalyst was same as that of Ni/NiMoN sample except that only 6 mmol Na2MoO4·2H2O and 15 mL of HNO3 (1.0 M) solution were added in a hydrothermal process. 2.6 Characterizations XRD patterns were recorded in Bruke D8 equipped with Cu-K α (λ = 1.5406 Å) radiation and Rigaku Mini-flex600 diffractometer. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was carried out on ZEISS Sigma-500 instrument with accelerating voltage of 5 kV. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping characterizations were performed on JEM-F200 electron microscope (JEOL, Japan) with operating voltage of 200 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out using a VG ESCALABMK II with Mg-K α radiation (1253.6 eV). The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller method was performed to calculate the specific surface area (77 K). Contact angle and adhesion tests were performed by using Lauda Scientific LSA100 from Germany. For the contact angle experiment, the catalyst was first pressed onto the substrate to form a flat surface, and then 10 μL of water was dropped onto the flat surface. For the underwater bubble contact angle test, the bubble volume is 10 μL and the tableting pressure is 10 MPa. The adhesion test conditions are as follows: bubble volume is 10 μL, lifting stage moving speed is 0.6 mm min−1, and a contact threshold is 3 mg. 2.7 Electrochemical measurements All the electrochemical measurements were performed on the CHI electrochemical workstation (model 760E) with a three-electrode system at 25 °C. The Hg/HgO electrode and carbon rod were used as reference electrode and counter electrode, respectively. The working electrode was prepared by mixing 5 mg of catalyst and 1 mg of carbon black dispersed in 50 μL of water/ethanol (v/v = 1:1) solution. Then, 30 μL Nafion was added to get the catalyst slurry. Subsequently, the catalyst slurry was scraped on the cleaned nickel foam (1.0 × 1.0 cm2). Before the electrochemical measurements, the electrolyte solutions (1 M KOH and 1 M phosphate buffered solutions (PBS)) were bubbled with N2 for 1 h to remove the dissolved gases. The polarization curves were recorded using linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) test at a scan rate of 2 mV s−1, which was performed after 20 cycles of cyclic voltammetry (CV) tests. All the reported potentials were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) according to E RHE = E HgO/Hg + 0.059 × pH + E θ HgO/Hg. Tafel plots were derived from polarization curves. The Tafel slope reveals the dependence of the compensation overpotential on the current density, which can be calculated by the Tafel equation η = a + blogj, where η is the UOR potential, b is the Tafel slope, and j is the measured current [23]. CV curve was performed at a scan rate of 10–80 mV s−1 in the non-faradaic potential range to estimate the electrochemical double layer capacitance (C dl). The stability of the catalysts was evaluated by performing CV cycles and chronoamperometry test. All tests were performed without IR corrections. The electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) is the electrochemical active surface area, which can be calculated from the following formula. ECSA = specific capacitance / 40 μF cm - 2 where specific capacitance is C dl, and 40 μF cm−2 is constant to convert capacitance to ECSA. The specific capacitance can be converted into ECSA using the specific capacitance value for flat standard with 1 cm2 of real surface area. Turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated by supposing every corresponding metal atom as active sites involved in catalytic reaction, as shown the equation TOF = j S / z F n where j is measured current density (mA cm−2); S is geometrical surface area of working electrode (1 cm−2); z is electron transfer number per molecule generated H2 (z = 2 for HER); F is Faraday’s constant (96485.3 C mol−1); and n is the moles of the corresponding metal atom (mol) within the catalyst loading. The faradaic efficiency (FE) for HER was calculated by comparing the experimentally determined and theoretically calculated amounts of H2. In the two-electrode cell, the generated hydrogen was collected via a simple drainage method. Constant potential electrolysis was performed at 33 mA cm−2 for 60 min in closed H-shaped electrolytic cell. The theoretical H2 amount was calculated as follows. n H 2 = Q / z F where n(H2), Q, and F are the moles of produced hydrogen, the electrode charge, and Faraday's constant (96485 C mol−1), respectively. z is the number of electrons transferred during water splitting (for HER, z = 2). 2.8 Theoretical calculation Density functional theory (DFT) simulations were performed by employing Cambridge Sequential Total Energy Package (CASTEP) module implemented in Material Studio. The generalized gradient approximation (GGA) with Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used to describe the electronic exchange and correlation effects, and the plane-wave energy cutoff was set to 500 eV. The self-consistent field (SCF) tolerance was 2 × 10−5 eV. To calculate the adsorption energy, the (111), (001), and (100) surfaces respectively for Ni, NiMoN, and Ni/NiMoN catalysts were modeled with vacuum width of 15 Å to avoid periodic interactions along the surface normal. The lattice vectors that are used to generate the corresponding crystal planes were [100] (axis a) and [010] (axis b) for NiMoN (001) surface, [1−10] (axis a) and [01−1] (axis b) for Ni (111) surface, and [010] (axis a) and [001] (axis b) for Ni/NiMoN (100) surface. A (3 × 3 × 1) Monkhorst-Pack mesh was used to perform geometry optimization, during which the convergence was established when the total energy change was smaller than 2 × 10−5 eV and the force on the atoms was less than 0.05 eV Å−1. The adsorption free energies of H (ΔG H*) is an effective descriptor for HER activity and the catalyst with ΔG H*=0 is an excellent candidate for HER. The Gibbs free-energy of H*(ΔG H*) can be calculated by the equation ΔG H* = ΔE H* + ΔE ZPE − TΔS, where ΔE H* is the adsorption energy of atomic hydrogen on the given unit cell; ΔE ZPE and ΔS are the difference corresponding to the zero-point energy between the adsorbed hydrogen and hydrogen in the gas phase and the entropy change of H* adsorption, respectively. ΔS can be obtained by ΔS = S (H*) − 1/2S 0 H2 (S 0 H2 is the entropy of H2 in the gas phase at standard conditions). As the entropy of hydrogen in absorbed state is negligible, ΔS can be calculated as −1/2S 0 H2. Therefore, the Gibbs free energy of H* can be taken as: ΔG H* = ΔE H*+ 0.24 eV. The adsorption energy (E ads) is given by the following equation: E ads = E system − E substrate − E adsorbate, where E system refers to the total energy of the optimized system; E substrate and E adsorbate refer to the energy of adsorbed layer and isolated adsorbate molecules, respectively. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization The preparation process of the 3D hollow Ni/NiMoN nano-sheet arrays is schematically depicted in Fig. 1 (a). Initially, the NiMoO4 nanoflower precursor is synthesized through a simple hydrothermal process. After nitridation in NH3 atmosphere, the green powder turns black and the products exhibits noticeable magnetism, which is conducive to the separation of catalyst. The structure of the precursor is described via SEM and TEM. The SEM image (Fig. S1a) indicates the formation of 3D flower-like structure assembled from two-dimensional (2D) nano-sheet arrays with smooth surfaces. The formation of flower-like structure should be related with the use of urea as “slow-release” alkali [39]. Notably, the product shows rod-like structure without adding urea (Fig. S1b). The TEM images further confirm the 3D hollow structure of the NiMoO4 precursor (Fig. S1c and d). The scanning TEM (STEM) image and the elemental mappings (Fig. S1e) demonstrate the homogeneous distribution of Ni, Mo, and O throughout the nanosheets. After the nitriding, the diffraction peaks of the sample (Fig. 1b) can be allocated to the Ni metal (JCPDS:89-7128) and Ni0.2Mo0.8N (JCPDS:89-5026) phases, indicating the successful preparation of Ni/NiMoN compound. The SEM images of Ni/NiMoN (Fig. 1c and d) show a flower-like morphology assembled from 2D nano-sheet arrays without collapsing, being similar to that of the precursor. The high-magnification SEM images reveal the rough surface of Ni/NiMoN sample, which is beneficial for exposing more active sites. The 3D hierarchical nano-sheet arrays structure can effectively promote the electrolyte diffusion and the release of air bubbles during electrocatalysis [14,18,20]. All these characteristics contribute to the improvement of electrocatalytic performance. TEM test was conducted to give further insights into the structure and composition information. The TEM image (Fig. 1e) indicates the apparent hollow structure. The high-magnification TEM image further demonstrates the rough surface of nanosheets and there are some nanoparticles at the edges of the nanosheets (Fig. 1f). The adjacent lattice fringes of the (200) planes of Ni and (100) planes of Ni0.2Mo0.8N can be obviously observed in high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Fig. 1g), confirming the formation of Ni0.2Mo0.8N and Ni heterointerfaces. The construction of heterogeneous surfaces promotes the electron redistribution, leading to effective synergistic catalysis [21]. In electrocatalytic reactions, the heterogeneous interfaces adjust the surrounding electronic environment, expose numerous active sites, enhance electron transfer, and optimize the adsorption/desorption of reactants and intermediates, thus enhancing the performance largely [40,41]. The elemental mapping (Fig. 1h) displays the uniform distribution of Mo, Ni, and N elements in the Ni/NiMoN catalyst. Additionally, EDX line scanning was conducted to study the elemental distribution of particles in Ni/NiMoN nano-sheet arrays. Two lines (L1 and L2 in Fig. S2) were selected to detect Ni, Mo, and N elements. As shown in Fig. S2, the Ni, Mo, and N elements are evenly distributed throughout the entire Ni/NiMoN nano-sheet arrays, consistent with the EDX mapping results. XPS analysis was carried out to analyze elemental composition and the surface chemical states of the samples. The XPS survey spectra of Ni/NiMoN and NiMoN-24E samples display the existence of Ni, Mo, N, C, and O elements (Fig. 2 a). The survey spectrum of Ni/NiMoN shows the coexistence of Mo with Ni and N elements, which agrees well with the EDX results. As shown in Ni 2p spectrum (Fig. 2b), the peaks at 873.4 and 855.7 eV can be attributed to Ni2+ 2p 1/2 and Ni2+ 2p 3/2 from the Ni, respectively [42]. The weaker peaks at 869.5 and 852.4 eV can be identified as Ni0 from the metallic Ni [43]. The relative content of Ni to NiMoN-24E was further determined by calculating the peak areas of Ni0 and Ni2+ displayed in the Ni 2p spectrum. The peak area of Ni0 accounts for 30.04 at%, and that of Ni2+ accounts for 6.92 at%. The ratio of Ni to NiMoN-24E is 1:4.34 (Table S2) [44,45]. The Ni 2p peaks of Ni/NiMoN exhibit a positive shift of 0.4 eV compared to the Ni sample, indicating that electrons transfer from Ni to the nearby atoms [46]. The Mo 3d spectrum (Fig. 2c) shows that there are three valence states (+3, +4, and +6) in Ni/NiMoN catalyst [47]. The peaks observed at 228.9 and 232.4 eV indicate the presence of Mo3+ in metal nitride. These Mo3+ ions can be considered as the main active center for HER due to following characteristics [48]. For example, an unfilled d orbital of Mo3+ can better participate in the electron transfer process to promote the electrochemical reactions [49]. The vacancy energy level on Mo3+ is favorable to catalyzing water dissociation and the generation of hydrogen atoms [50]. Moreover, Mo3+ is more stable in water than Mo with other valence states, being favorable to maintaining long-term activity [51]. Meanwhile, the Mo 3d 5/2/3d 3/2 peaks of Mo4+ and Mo6+ are located at 230.3/233.4 eV and 231.9/235.2 eV, respectively [52,53]. The Mo 3d peaks for Ni/NiMoN shift negatively by 0.3 eV compared to that of the NiMoN-24E sample. The above results indicate that there is an interaction between Ni and NiMoN-24E, which leads to the redistribution of electrons at the hetero-interface and the adjustment of the electronic structure, thus improving the electrocatalytic performance. Fig. 2(d) displays the spectrum of N 1s. The peak at 397.1 eV corresponds to N bonding to Mo/Ni, further indicating the formation of the nitride. Meanwhile, the peak at 394.8 eV corresponds to Mo 3p 3/2. The peak located at 399.1 eV can be attributed to the N–H groups, suggesting the abundance of H species on the surface of samples [54]. These surface H species may originate from an incomplete reaction with NH3. The result suggests that the surface N ions can interact strongly with H species, which is beneficial for promoting HER [55]. XPS analysis confirms the presence of Ni, Mo, and N corresponding to the Ni/NiMoN compounds. It also indicates the occurrence of electron transfer between Ni and NiMoN-24E components. This transfer leads to the redistribution of electrons at the heterogeneous interface, thereby modulating the electronic structure and improving the catalytic performance [17] To investigate the phase and morphology evolution process of the 3D hollow hierarchical nano-sheet arrays structure, the temperature-dependent experiments were performed. The formation process of the hybrid structure was detected by XRD, TEM, and SEM. Fig. S3(a and d) shows the XRD patterns of Ni/NiMoN-5 and Ni/NiMoN-7 samples. The peak position is the same as that of the Ni/NiMoN sample, but the intensity has a certain change, indicating that the crystallinity of the catalyst can be effectively controlled. From the TEM and SEM images of Ni/NiMoN-5 (Fig. S3 b and c), the morphology of nanoflowers assembled from nano-sheet arrays can be maintained. Nevertheless, as the temperature rises to 700 °C, the Ni/NiMoN-7 sample exhibits significant aggregation phenomenon (Fig. S3e and f), which reduces the exposure of active sites. Furthermore, the contrastive samples (Ni and Mo3N2) were also characterized by XRD and SEM. As depicted in Figs. S4 and S5, the Ni sample exhibits nanoparticle morphology, and the Mo3N2 sample shows the morphology of aggregated nanoribbons. Fig. S6 shows the N2 adsorption/desorption isotherms of Ni/NiMoN catalysts. The specific surface area of the Ni/NiMoN is 60.8 m2 g−1, larger than that of Ni/NiMoN-5 (46.6 m2 g−1) and Ni/NiMoN-7 (35.2 m2 g−1), which is favorable for the mass transfer and the contact between electrolyte and active sites to promote electrocatalysis. Considering that the reaction process takes place at the three-phase interface of solid-liquid-gas, it involves both the generation and release of gas. Therefore, mass transfer and bubble release have a significant impact on the overall electrocatalytic efficiency [22]. According to the droplet contact angle measurements (the upper panel of Fig. 3a–c), it was observed that the Ni/NiMoN sample displayed a small droplet contact angle (CA) of 6.07°, indicating its super-hydrophilic nature in comparison to the NiMoN-6E (CA = 17.49°) and Ni (CA = 47.60°) samples, proving that the Ni/NiMoN sample was super-hydrophilic. Besides, underwater bubble contact angle analysis (the lower panel of Fig. 3a–c) revealed that Ni/NiMoN exhibited the bubble contact angle of is 155.7°, while Ni and NiMoN-6E showed bubble contact angles of 144.0° and 154.5°, respectively. This reflects the good aerophobicity performance of Ni/NiMoN [38]. Moreover, the superaerophobic properties of Ni/NiMoN were further proved by testing the adhesive force of bubbles to the electrode surface in water [18]. As shown in Fig. 3(d), the bubble adhesion force on the Ni/NiMoN catalyst is 28.81 μN, which is even lower than the reported 76.0 μN of adhesive force for Pt nanosphere films [56]. The results demonstrate that the complex nano-sheet arrays structure of the Ni/NiMoN catalyst creates a superoxophobic surface that significantly reduces bubble adhesion [20]. The low adhesive force is beneficial for enhancing gas bubble separation from the electrode surface, thereby improving the performance. In a word, owing to the unique 3D hollow hierarchical nano-sheet arrays structure and chemical composition, the Ni/NiMoN sample is super-hydrophilic and aerophobicity. When Ni/NiMoN is used as the catalysts for HER and UOR, the super-hydrophilic surface will promote the effective contact between the reactants and catalyst in the electrolyte, and the aerophobicity surface will enhance the emission of the generated bubbles (H2, N2, and CO2) [21,56]. Thus, the good mass transfer kinetics and the catalytic properties of Ni/NiMoN for HER and UOR can be ensured. 3.2 Electrocatalytic performance The electrocatalytic performance of the Ni/NiMoN catalysts was assessed in a three-electrode system. To avoid any possible effect of Pt, graphite rod was used as counter electrode. The HER catalytic activity of the as-prepared catalysts was measured mainly in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte and the polarization curves without iR rectification were gained by LSV tests. Fig. 4 (a) displays the polarization curves of different samples. A rapidly increased cathodic current response for the Ni/NiMoN sample is observed at low overpotentials, indicating its excellent HER activity. Several materials are commonly used as substrate for supporting the electrocatalysts, primarily including foam nickel (NF) and carbon paper (CP). In present work, the catalytic performance of Ni/NiMoN on CP substrate is slightly inferior to that on NF substrate. Additionally, the bare NF substrate showed a poor activity with the onset potential of 256 mV and the overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 (η 10) of 345 mV, implying its minimal effect on the HER performance of Ni/NiMoN catalyst (Fig. S7). In Fig. 4(b) and Fig. S8(a), the Ni/NiMoN catalyst needs low overpotentials of 25 and 130 mV to reach 10 and 100 mA cm−2 current density, respectively, much smaller than those of Ni (145 and 331 mV), Mo3N2 (173 and 333 mV), Ni/NiMoN-5 (35 and 186 mV), and Ni/NiMoN-7 (76 and 290 mV), as well as close to commercial 20% Pt/C (19 and 117 mV) catalysts, indicating that the construction of heterointerface and 3D architecture can significantly improve electrocatalytic performance. The heterointerface may modulate electron distribution and enhance electron transfer, thereby promoting the adsorption/desorption of both intermediates and reactants. To better explain the collaborative effect between Ni and NiMoN, the prepared Ni/NiMoN sample was immersed in 2 M HCl and stirred for different times to remove a certain amount of metal nickel in Ni/NiMoN catalyst to reduce the heterointerface. With the increase of etching time, the peak intensity of Ni decreased gradually in the XRD patterns (Fig. S9a), indicating that the content of metal nickel in the sample is getting less and less. The change in the proportion of metal after etching was also confirmed by inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometer (ICP-OES). According to the results of the ICP-OES test, the ratio of Ni to Mo in Ni/NiMoN catalyst is 1.25:1. The ratio of Ni to Mo in NiMoN-6E, NiMoN-12E, and NiMoN-24E is 1:6.63, 1:8.69, and 1:14.98, respectively. With the increase of etching time, the proportion of nickel gradually decreases. This demonstrates the successful etching of the nickel metal (Table S3). As shown in Fig. S9(b), with the increase of soaking time, the HER activity of the obtained samples becomes worse, which further proves that the construction of heterointerface can effectively promote the catalytic activity. Tafel slope values were subsequently computed to explain the inherent catalytic kinetics of as-prepared catalysts. As displayed in Fig. 4(c) and Fig. S8(b), Ni/NiMoN catalyst has low Tafel slope value of 49 mV dec−1, which is close to the standard commercial Pt/C catalysts (43 mV dec−1) and smaller than the other contrast samples, indicating that the HER kinetics of Ni/NiMoN is faster than that of other catalysts and the HER on Ni/NiMoN catalysts should follow the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism. As shown in Fig. S10, the exchange current density (j 0) of Ni/NiMoN is 2.51 mA cm−2, larger than Ni/NiMoN-5 (1.58 mA cm−2), Ni/NiMoN-7 (0.71 mA cm−2), Ni (0.99 mA cm−2), Mo3N2 (0.35 mA cm−2), and NiMoN-6E (1.98 mA cm−2), suggesting the remarkable H2 evolution activity of the Ni/NiMoN. The C dl is roughly proportional to the ECSA, which was measured by CV within the non-faradaic potential region (0.12–0.22 V vs. RHE) at different scan rates (Fig. S11). The C dl value of Ni/NiMoN is 85.0 mF cm−2 (Fig. 4d and Fig. S12a), larger than that of the other studied electrocatalysts. The high C dl value of Ni/NiMoN catalyst suggests the presence of numerous catalytic active sites, contributing to good HER performance. Thanks to the flower-like structure and rich phase boundaries in the catalyst, the ECSA of Ni/NiMoN (2125 cm2) is twice that of the NiMoN-6E (1005 cm2), and much larger than that of the Ni (485 cm2) and Mo3N2 (235 cm2) catalysts (Fig. S12b). Moreover, the ECSA-normalized LSV curves show that Ni/NiMoN catalyst has higher current density than the other catalysts at the same potential (Fig. S12c and d), suggesting a higher intrinsic per-site activity of the Ni/NiMoN catalyst. In addition, the TOF of the samples was tested. At an overpotential of 100 mV, Ni/NiMoN exhibited a higher TOF value (0.519 s−1) compared to the other samples, suggesting additional highly active sites of Ni/NiMoN (Fig. S13). Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were performed to assess the charge transfer resistance (R ct) of the catalyst. In Fig. 4(e), semicircular shapes are showed by fitting the EIS data. The corresponding fitted equivalent circuit model is shown in the inset in Fig. 4(e). The smaller R ct proves faster catalytic kinetics and higher charge transfer rate [57]. The Ni/NiMoN catalyst has a smaller R ct of 4.7 Ω at the electrode/electrolyte interface compared to other catalysts, indicating the faster electron transport during the electrocatalytic reaction. The stability of Ni/NiMoN was also evaluated (Fig. 4f). The polarization curves of Ni/NiMoN catalyst after 3000 and 8000 cycles of CV testing almost overlap with the initial one. In addition, the I-t curve reveals that the current density slightly decays after the Ni/NiMoN catalyst is continuously operated for 96 h, demonstrating excellent stability of Ni/NiMoN for HER (insert in Fig. 4f). The samples were subsequently analyzed by XRD, SEM, and XPS after the stability test. The SEM image (Fig. S14a) shows that the Ni/NiMoN still maintains hierarchical structure after HER test. The XRD pattern (Fig. S14b) presents the similar diffraction peaks before and after the HER test, indicating that the crystal phase has not changed. Furthermore, the XPS spectra of Ni 2p and Mo 3d also demonstrate similar peaks to the original spectra (Fig. S14c and d), further proving the structural stability of Ni/NiMoN. The contents of Mo and Ni in catalyst and electrolyte after HER were also analyzed by ICP-OES (Table S3). After HER test, the Mo content of Ni/NiMoN catalyst slightly decreases, while the Mo is detected in the electrolyte. This indicates the dissolution of Mo in the catalyst during the HER test. The dissolved Mo contributes to the HER activity and durability of Ni/NiMoN through dissolution-re-deposition cycles [53]. Overall, these experimental results indicate that the Ni/NiMoN catalyst exhibits excellent stability for HER. Moreover, the HER activity of Ni/NiMoN is superior to the most reported NiMo-based catalysts (Fig. 4g and Table S4). The results indicate the Ni/NiMoN catalyst shows good HER activity and stability in 1.0 M KOH solution. We further evaluated the electrocatalytic performance of Ni/NiMoN catalysts in neutral media (1.0 M PBS). As shown in Fig. 5 (a and b) and Fig. S15(a), Ni/NiMoN displays superior electrocatalytic behavior for HER (η 10 = 68 mV), exceeding NiMoN-6E (η 10 = 142 mV), Ni (η 10 = 251 mV), Mo3N2 (η 10 = 290 mV), Ni/NiMoN-5 (η 10 = 100 mV), Ni/NiMoN-7 (η 10 = 181 mV), and most of reported catalysts (Fig. 5g and Table S5). Fig. 5(c) exhibits that the Tafel slope of Ni/NiMoN is 60 mV dec−1, which is lower than that of the other samples. The low Tafel slope suggests that Ni/NiMoN catalyst also obeys the Volmer-Heyrovsky mechanism in the neutral solution. In addition, Ni/NiMoN catalyst has much larger j 0 value than Ni/NiMoN-5, Ni/NiMoN-7, NiMoN-6E, Mo3N2, and Ni catalysts (Fig. S15c and d), further demonstrating its good HER performance in 1.0 M PBS. The C dl values of different samples were also computed (Fig. S16a–f). The C dl value for Ni/NiMoN-5, Ni/NiMoN, Ni/NiMoN-7, Mo3N2, Ni, and NiMoN-6E catalysts is 35.7, 64.8, 12.9, 5.1, 13.8, and 33.5 mF cm−2, respectively (Fig. 5d and Fig. S16g). The larger C dl value and higher current density from the ECSA normalized polarization curves (Fig. S16h) indicate that the Ni/NiMoN has visible advantage in terms of catalytic active sites and active surface area over other catalysts. Moreover, Ni/NiMoN catalyst presents the fastest charge transfer rate among the as-prepared catalysts (Fig. 5e), because of the synergism of NiMoN and Ni. Besides, the Ni/NiMoN heterojunction catalyst also displays excellent durability in 1.0 M PBS solution (Fig. 5f). The Ni/NiMoN heterojunction retains significant activity after 80 h of continuous testing in 1 M PBS electrolyte (the inset of Fig. 5f). To achieve the energy-saving H2 production, UOR was selected to replace the sluggish OER [23]. The UOR and OER activity of Ni/NiMoN catalyst was assessed by LSV in 1.0 M KOH with 0.5 M urea and 1.0 M KOH, respectively. As displayed in Fig. 6 (a), the Ni/NiMoN catalyst achieves a lower UOR onset potential of 1.31 V (vs. RHE), and the current density increases rapidly after the potential is exceeded. In addition, Ni/NiMoN catalyst needs the cell voltage of 1.39 V to reach 100 mA cm−2 current density in catalytic UOR, which is 277 mV lower than that in the OER. The result indicates that UOR is more favorable than OER at low potential. Furthermore, the UOR current density of the Ni/NiMoN catalyst was higher than that of Ni/NiMoN-5, Ni/NiMoN-7, NiMoN-6E, NiMoN-24E, Ni, Mo3N2, and RuO2 at the potential of 1.395 V (Fig. 6b and Fig. S17a), suggesting that the formation of heterojunctions can significantly improve the UOR activity. Additionally, to determine the role of Mo in the catalyst, we synthesized a Ni/NiN catalyst following a methodology similar to the Ni/NiMoN. As displayed in Fig. S18, the Ni/NiN catalyst exhibits inferior HER and UOR performance compared to Ni/NiMoN catalysts, revealing that the synergy between Ni and Mo is beneficial for improving catalytic performance. The UOR kinetics of Ni/NiMoN catalysts was explored. The Ni/NiMoN catalyst has a small Tafel slope of 22 mV dec−1, smaller than that of Ni/NiMoN-5 (35 mV dec−1), Ni/NiMoN-7 (49 mV dec−1), NiMoN-6E (39 mV dec−1), Ni (50 mV dec−1), Mo3N2 (75 mV dec−1), and RuO2 (66 mV dec−1) samples (Fig. 6c and Fig. S17b), demonstrating the fast electron transfer rate and a superior UOR catalytic kinetics of the Ni/NiMoN catalyst. In addition, based on the obtained CVs (Fig. S19a–f), the Ni/NiMoN catalyst has the largest C dl value (72.2 mF cm−2) compared with other catalysts (Fig. 6d and Fig. S19g). Moreover, the ECSA of Ni/NiMoN (1805 cm2) is much larger than that of NiMoN-6E (1202.5 cm2), Ni (497.5 cm2), Mo3N2 (285 cm2), Ni/NiMoN-5 (1372.5 cm2), and Ni/NiMoN-7 (622.5 cm2) catalysts (Fig. S19h). The results showed that the controlled nitridation treatment to construct 3D hollow flower-like structures can effectively increase the exposure of catalytic active sites, thus contributing significantly to improve the catalytic activity. In addition, the EIS was performed to investigate the UOR kinetics. In Fig. 6(e), the Ni/NiMoN catalyst has the lowest R ct value (4.2 Ω), in agreement with the Tafel slope, further confirming its good UOR charge transfer kinetic properties. The Ni/NiMoN catalyst shows a low Tafel slope, large ECSA, and small charge transfer resistance, implying a good UOR performance, which is superior to most of the non-noble metal catalysts reported recently (Table S6). In comparison to the Mo3N2 sample, the enhanced catalytic activity of the Ni/NiMoN, Ni, and NiMoN-6E catalysts suggests that the Ni species may serve as the electrocatalytically active sites of UOR [33]. For these Ni-based materials, the formation of Ni3+ (NiOOH) during the anodization process has been identified as the catalytic active site [31,35]. The long-term stability of the catalysts was also measured. Notably, the LSV curve of the Ni/NiMoN catalyst displays a slight variation at high current density after 3000 and 5000 cycles (Fig. 6f), demonstrating its excellent catalytic stability. More, the chronoamperometric response of the catalyst at 1.33 V shows that the current density remains reasonably stable for 72 h of continuous operation (the inset of Fig. 6f). The SEM images (Fig. S20a and b) reveal that the morphology of the Ni/NiMoN catalyst is slightly changed, but still possesses the structure of nanosheets. TEM image (Fig. S20c) further shows the formation of many small nanolayers, which proves that the structural recombination occurs during the UOR process. The HRTEM image (Fig. S20d) displays the clear amorphous layer with thickness approximately 5 nm. It is inferred that the amorphous layer (nickel hydrogen oxide or nickel oxygen) was formed in situ on NiMoN [31,32]. The XRD pattern (Fig. S20e) of the post-UOR sample is consistent with that of the fresh catalyst. The XPS results (Fig. S20f and g) reveal the formation of Ni3+ and the increased Mo6+ content after UOR treatment. These results are caused by the surface corrosion and oxidation of Ni/NiMoN to produce the corresponding oxide/oxy(hydroxide) species, which can further optimize the oxidation activity as main UOR species [33]. ICP-OES analysis was conducted to determine the Mo and Ni contents in the catalyst and electrolyte after UOR. Table S3 demonstrates that the electrolyte contains a low level of Ni and high-level of Mo throughout the process. This observation suggests that the surface reconstruction process of Ni/NiMoN is rapid and self-terminating, preventing complete reconstruction and forming stable high-valent Ni active structures. The Mo in Ni/NiMoN is assumed to be oxidized and subsequently dissolved in the electrolyte, leaving the amorphous nickel hydrogen oxide or nickel oxygen [27]. The above results clearly indicate the outstanding stability of Ni/NiMoN for UOR in the alkaline environment. The molecular structure of urea is intricate, featuring both electron-donating amino (NH2) groups and electron-withdrawing carbonyl (CO) groups [58]. The adsorption behavior of urea on catalysts has a significant impact on the reaction dynamics of UOR. To elucidate the crucial role of the NH2 and CO groups in UOR, we investigated the electro-oxidation reaction of urea analogues (methylurea and thiourea here) on Ni/NiMoN catalyst (Fig. S21). In this case, the O or H atom in urea is substituted with a S atom or a methyl group. The Ni/NiMoN catalyst shows low catalytic activity for both methylurea and thiourea oxidation. This outcome highlights the influence of the groups present in the reactants (such as urea) on the adsorption of reactant molecules in the oxidation reaction [33]. Meanwhile, the influence of urea on the HER performance of the Ni/NiMoN catalyst was also evaluated (Fig. S22), and it was found that the difference in the HER polarization curves in the presence of urea was negligible, indicating that the catalyst can resist urea interference during the HER and can be used as an electrode to promote H2 generation in coupled HER and UOR systems. 3.3 DFT calculations DFT calculations were performed to gain insights into the synergistic effects of heterogeneous surface engineering of Ni/NiMoN on enhancing the electrocatalytic activity of UOR and HER (Fig. S23a). Theoretical models of single-phase NiMoN and Ni were also built as a comparison (Fig. S23b and c). The charge density differences (Fig. 7 a) indicate the presence of electron aggregation at the interface, with the pink and blue regions being the electron depletion and electron accumulation regions, respectively [8]. The results confirm the existence of the strong charge interaction between Ni and NiMoN. To get a better understanding of the effect of d-electron modulation on the electrocatalytic performance of HER, the density of states (DOS) was calculated for Ni, NiMoN, and Ni/NiMoN, respectively (Fig. 7b). DFT calculations display that the d-band centers (ε d ) of Ni/NiMoN, Ni, and NiMoN are −0.90, −1.25, and −0.72 eV, respectively. The εd value of Ni is the farthest from the Fermi level (E f), indicating that the Ni catalyst is not conducive to adsorption. On the other hand, the εd value of NiMoN is closer to the E f, indicating stronger adsorption capability of the active sites on the NiMoN surface for reaction intermediates. In the heterostructure formed by Ni and NiMoN, the interfacial electric field within the heterojunction regulates the d-band center at different locations, thereby enhancing the electronic environment around the metal. This improvement results in enhanced adsorption performance for intermediates and achieves an equilibrium state of adsorption and desorption. Compared with single-phase NiMoN and Ni, Ni/NiMoN heterojunction has a moderate d-band center to reach the adsorption-desorption equilibrium, thus optimizing the Gibbs free energy of hydrogen adsorption (ΔG H*) and improving the inherent electrocatalytic activity [1,33]. Furthermore, the continuous distribution of the density of states near the Fermi energy level in Fig. 7(c) suggests the Ni/NiMoN has good electrical conductivity, indicating the fast electron transport [59]. ΔG H* serves as a key parameter for evaluating the HER activity. To achieve optimal hydrogen adsorption and desorption strength, the ΔG H* value should be close to zero. We conducted calculations to determine the ΔG H* on different sites, as depicted in Fig. 7(d). In the Ni/NiMoN catalyst, the ΔG H* value of the N site (−0.07 eV) is closer to zero compared to that of the Ni site (−0.7 eV) and Mo site (−0.62 eV), indicating that the adsorption of H on N sites is more active than that on Ni and Mo sites. Furthermore, by comparing the ΔG H* value of different sites of Ni (0.17 eV) and NiMoN (−0.88 eV), it is observed that Ni/NiMoN exhibits more favorable H* adsorption kinetics for HER. Therefore, the introduction of N adjusts the surrounding electronic environment and influences the d-band center, ultimately affecting the adsorption capacity of different intermediates and optimizing the catalytic activity [58,60]. Additionally, five main stages were considered in the DFT calculations, including water adsorption, dissociation to form H* intermediates (Volmer step), and hydrogen gas generation (Tafel step or Heyrovsky step). The free energy diagram of the model is shown in Fig. 7(e). The results indicate that Ni and NiMoN require overcoming higher energy barriers (0.79 and 0.98 eV) in the process of *[OH–H] to *H. Conversely, the energy barrier for Ni/NiMoN is considerably lower (0.53 eV), suggesting that the formation of the heterojunction can effectively enhances the kinetics of the HER process. Therefore, Ni synergistically promotes the thermodynamics and kinetics of alkaline HER with NiMoN, which is consistent with the experimental results. Meanwhile, the adsorption energy of H2O and urea on Ni, NiMoN, and Ni/NiMoN heterojunction catalysts is calculated (Fig. 7f and Fig. S24). The water adsorption energy of Ni/NiMoN heterojunction (−0.60 eV) is lower than that of Ni (−0.50 eV) and NiMoN (−0.11 eV), suggesting that heterostructure catalyst is prone to the initial catalytic-H2O state, which is favorable for the HER process in alkaline electrolyte. Meanwhile, Ni/NiMoN heterojunction catalyst has a more negative urea adsorption energy (−0.68 eV) compared to NiMoN (−0.30 eV) and Ni (−0.12 eV), which suggests that the Ni/NiMoN heterojunction can effectively bind and enhance the individual component advantage, optimizing the adsorption of urea molecules at a large extent, thereby achieving efficient urea oxidation performance. The redistribution of charges during the catalytic reaction directly affects the adsorption/desorption energy of intermediate and enhances the separation of water and urea [11,61]. The results of DFT calculations show that the construction of Ni/NiMoN heterostructures can effectively tune the electronic structure, thereby Optimizing adsorption/desorption of reactants and intermediates to improve electrocatalytic performance. 3.4 Urea assisted water electrolysis performance Based on the outstanding HER and UOR electrocatalytic performance of Ni/NiMoN electrode, the energy-saving H2 production system was constructed, using Ni/NiMoN as both anode and cathode for UOR and HER. For comparison, the traditional electrolytic water (HER and OER) was also carried out. The polarization curves of HER&UOR system and the traditional HER&OER system are shown in Fig. 8 (a). The Ni/NiMoN||Ni/NiMoN coupled HER&UOR system needs only 1.42 V cell voltage to obtain the current density of 10 mA cm−2, significantly smaller than traditional water splitting (1.61 V). In addition, the HER&UOR system shows greater advantages with the increase of current density (Fig. 8b), indicating that substituting OER with UOR is an efficient way for energy-efficient H2 production. Moreover, the overall electrocatalytic performance of Ni/NiMoN||Ni/NiMoN is even superior to the noble metal-based catalysts (Pt/C||RuO2) (Fig. 8c and d). The long-term stability of the catalyst in the HER&UOR system was tested. As shown in Fig. 8(e), only a slight decay in current density was observed after chronoamperometric test for 96 h, showing the high stability of Ni/NiMoN||Ni/NiMoN for urea electrolysis system. The produced hydrogen was measured by the drainage method (Fig. 8g). The Faradaic efficiency in HER was measured to be 98.9% (Fig. 8f), indicating that the Ni/NiMoN catalyst has a strong ability of hydrogen production in the HER&UOR system. For practical applications, building solar systems is a prospective approach to achieve economical and continual H2 production. Fig. 8(h) shows that the HER&UOR system can be driven by the solar panel at a lower battery voltage of 1.42 V. The anode generates N2 and CO2 bubbles through UOR, and the cathode generates and escapes H2 bubbles (Fig. 8i and Video S1). This result indicates that the 3D hollow flower-like structure not only facilitates the permeation of electrolytes and reactants, but also provides an efficient dispersion pathway for the quick release of gaseous products. In addition, the Ni/NiMoN||Ni/NiMoN shows better overall electrocatalytic performance than many reported noble metal-free catalysts (Table S7), indicating that the Ni/NiMoN can become a prospective electrode for the energy-efficient H2 production in the coupled HER&UOR system. 4 Conclusions In summary, we have proved that the hollow Ni/NiMoN materials are suitable as bifunctional electrocatalysts for HER and UOR. The design of a 3D hierarchical structure with arrayed-sheet surface provides the super-hydrophilic/aerophobic properties, causing the easy escape of bubbles from the electrode. The heterojunctions can promote the transfer of the electrons and modify the interface electronic structure, optimizing adsorption/desorption of reactants and intermediates. So, the Ni/NiMoN catalysts exhibit excellent HER performance close to that of Pt/C catalysts and excellent UOR performance. The cell voltage of the urea-assisted electrolytic H2 production system (HER&UOR) based on the catalyst dropped significantly to 1.42 V at 10 mA cm−2, 209 mV lower than traditional HER&OER system. This work shows that a combined manipulation of the surface property and electronic structure provides an effective way for designing effective catalysts. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and urea oxidation reaction (UOR) are key reactions of the water-cycling associated catalytic process/device. The design of catalysts with a super-hydrophilic/aerophobic structure and optimized electron distribution holds great promise. Here, we have designed a three-dimensional (3D) hollow Ni/NiMoN hierarchical structure with arrayed-sheet surface based on a one-pot hydrothermal route for efficient urea-assisted HER based on a simple hydrothermal process. The Ni/NiMoN catalyst exhibits super-hydrophilic/aerophobic properties with a small droplet contact angle of 6.07° and an underwater bubble contact angle of 155.7°, thus facilitating an escape of bubbles from the electrodes. Density functional theory calculations and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy results indicate the optimized electronic structure at the interface of Ni and NiMoN, which can promote the adsorption/desorption of reactants and intermediates. The virtues combining with a large specific surface area endow Ni/NiMoN with efficient catalytic activity of low potentials of 25 mV for HER and 1.33 V for UOR at 10 mA cm−2. The coupled HER and UOR system demonstrates a low cell voltage of 1.42 V at 10 mA cm−2, which is approximately 209 mV lower than water electrolysis.
